messageBody:
I thought people on the list might find this interesting. It is a
discussion of how to implement DBC in Java. I was alerted to it by the
latter link:

http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2002/jw-0215-dbcproxy.html
http://www.geocities.com/eliassonaand/project-home.html

I am not advocating this approach. I have first heard about DBC during
the "JUnit considered problematic" discussion here. Personally I like
using JUnit.

Either way I thought the article on how DBC could be applied to Java
might help inform our discussion. The article describes a way of
generating test cases from pre-conditions, post-conditions and
invariants in the javadoc /** */ comments before each class.

This certainly seems interesting to me. I certainly wouldn't use it as
a replacement for junit, but I would very much like to formalise the
relationship between method description, unit test and class documentation.

It seems to me that these DBC statements don't cover the full range of
possibilities covered by well-written tests in junit, but what would be
interesting would be to think about how to specify/document the range of
unit tests that a method or code segment must pass within the code itself.

CHEERS> SAM
